items.title: FAQ | United Kingdom Fulbright
items.summary: As a Fulbright Alumni Ambassador, I often receive emails from prospective U.S. applicants with great questions about the Fulbright application…
items.content_html:
As a Fulbright Alumni Ambassador, I often receive emails from prospective U.S. applicants with great questions about the Fulbright application and experience. This post includes real questions from real applicants. Keep in mind that many responses are geared towards a Study/Postgraduate Award in the U.K.. As mentioned in my Fulbright Guide, details about the Fulbright program vary from year to year and the opinions expressed here are my own. The ultimate source of accurate information is the official Fulbright website or by contacting IIE directly.

Table of Contents

  • Frequently Asked Questions
    • Should I contact the program's director or admissions? Were they receptive/helpful?
    • Do you know who I would contact about country specific questions?
    • What were the most challenging or unexpected aspects of your Fulbright experience?
    • How did you craft a compelling Statement of Grant Purpose for a degree program without falling into traps such as repeating what was listed on the university’s website?
    • Did you explore any distinctions in your field between the U.S. and the U.K.? Why did  you feel the U.K. was the right place for you to study?
    • How did you incorporate your international experience in your application?
    • Do I need a letter of affiliation? How do I get one?
    • One of my largest concerns is feeling like I am not good enough for the program and it is making writing my application difficult. What was your process for writing your application and what did you highlight that made you a stand out. 
    • Have you encountered any positives or negatives about pursuing and receiving a Master's degree abroad, as opposed to staying within the U.S.? 
    • Did you talk about specific courses or professors that interested you within the program? 
    • Did you specify in your Statement of Grant Purpose your intended dissertation on public transportation, or was that something you developed while studying at UCL?
    • In what ways did London add or detract from your experience at UCL? 
    • For Host Country Engagement, did you focus on ways to get involved within the UCL campus or with London in general? In what ways did you end up engaging with the community? 
    • Any other tips or tricks?
    • General Thoughts

Frequently Asked Questions

 

Should I contact the program's director or admissions? Were they receptive/helpful?

I contacted the program director during the summer of my application. Letters of affiliation for degree programs were still suggested when I applied. They were very receptive and helpful and that can be expected from most faculty and programs that you would contact about the Fulbright. I had limited contact with the faculty compared to those who applied for research awards.

Do you know who I would contact about country specific questions?

First make sure to review the country specific information on the website, for example here is the country page for the UK. Next, check if the country has a Fulbright commission. Most commissions will have a website or some web presence. Again, for example here is the UK Commission website. Depending on your question you can also

  1. Contact IIE
  2. Contact the commisson/embassy, UK Commission contact info
  3. Find a Fulbright Alumni Ambassador or other alum from the relevant country

What were the most challenging or unexpected aspects of your Fulbright experience?

Everyone's unexpected challenges are quite different. Everything from severe sickness to housing problems. Living in London, most of my unexpected challenges had to do with housing.

How did you craft a compelling Statement of Grant Purpose for a degree program without falling into traps such as repeating what was listed on the university’s website?

The website gives great info and lists the question at hand, "What are your reasons for selecting a particular institution?". To answer this question you should first speak to your current career trajectory/interests and then directly relate them to facts about the program you are applying to. For example, "I am studying the acute response of chimpanzees when they are shown pictures of cute golden retriever puppies. The program at France University has the most cute golden retriever puppies in the world and would further my research and professional development."

Did you explore any distinctions in your field between the U.S. and the U.K.? Why did  you feel the U.K. was the right place for you to study?

For my application, cultural differences were not front in center when drawing contrast between the program I was applying for and everything else out there. I made my case around the specific structure/benefits of the degree program I was applying for, which was structured quite differently than other MBA degrees, and offered clear alignment with my goals.

How did you incorporate your international experience in your application?

Integrating your previous international experience is very important. If you feel that your international experience ties in nicely with your "pitch" in the SOGP then put it there. Put less ambiguously, if your international experience is related to your academic/reserach topic or you gained knowledge that will be useful in your studies/research then include it in the SOGP. This will strengthen the (This is what I am interested in - This is what I have accomplished so far - This is why Fulbright is the best opportunity to further my career goals) pitch.

If your international experience is not directly related to the topic/theme of your SOGP then put it in the personal statement. The reality is that living abroad is no small feat. Many times the degree program is the least of your worries. The selection committee wants to ensure that all grantees will last the duration of the grant and it can be useful to discuss how you handled any difficulties while living abroad. 

Do I need a letter of affiliation? How do I get one?

Definitely visit the official website and look at the specific grant information. This may vary by country and Award. However, the information below might be accurate for most study grants in the UK.

  1. A letter of affiliation can be either a letter of admission or a letter of acceptance. Both can be accepted for review with the application, as an applicant can submit up to three letters of affiliation. If an applicant does not have a letter of admission, but wishes to add a letter from a department or professor specifically supporting their project they can add that.
  2. You are correct, admission to a university is required for final receipt of the Fulbright award. A letter of admission is not required at the time of application, but can be accepted, and must be presented in order to receive the award.
  3. A letter of affiliation is not needed, however, both a letter of affiliation or admittance does strengthen an applicant’s application.
  4. All letters of affiliation or admittance are reviewed by the National Screening Committees if they are received prior to October 8th. Further, if a candidate is moved on to semi-finalist status, any letters submitted with their application as well as any received in the interim can be reviewed by the UK Commission. Any letters can strengthen an applicant’s application, but there is no disadvantage for not having one either.

How do you get one? Many times this involves reaching out directly to faculty or program directors via emails found on the university website.

One of my largest concerns is feeling like I am not good enough for the program and it is making writing my application difficult. What was your process for writing your application and what did you highlight that made you a stand out. 

 
I appreciate your honesty and directness. Trust me you are not alone. Even those who receive a Fulbright wonder how they got it.
 
Focus on what you are passionate about and build a story around it. For example, I began with a little story about the small "businesses" I started as a kid (lemonade/crafts/lawncare) and how that tied into what I wanted to do with my career....and more importantly why the Fulbright was the best opportunity to achieve those career goals. Passion, competency, and a bit of blissful ignorance about the competition can make a great start to an application.
 
Be prepared to revise your application A LOT. I revised my application countless times with a Fulbright Program Advisor (may want to check in with your undergrad university, unless you are applying "at-large"). I also did not get the Fulbright the first time I applied for it. I know a few others have the same story.
 
Definitely check out some of the Fulbright webinars on application content. They often have Fulbright alumni talk about their applications.

Have you encountered any positives or negatives about pursuing and receiving a Master's degree abroad, as opposed to staying within the U.S.? 

Outside of Oxford and Cambridge (and maybe London School of Economics), I have found that there is very little name recognition for other globally ranked universities across the American business world (the opposite is true for the academic world). Ultimately, there is immense value in getting a Master's degree abroad from a well ranked university. Given the opportunity to redo everything, I would quickly pick the Fulbright and UCL degree over a Harvard MBA any day.

Did you talk about specific courses or professors that interested you within the program? 

Yes! Including this can help you to answer the question - [Why do you need to do this research/degree in this country at this university?] The MSc. Entrepreneurship at UCL is quite special because it essentially acts as a talent incubator. The program is set up to help students start and grow scalable companies, which was a core proposal in my SOGP. This is quite different from how MIT or Harvard structure their MBA programs. So, it offered a clear reason why UCL was one of the best, if not the best place, to pursue my goals.

Did you specify in your Statement of Grant Purpose your intended dissertation on public transportation, or was that something you developed while studying at UCL?

Great question. I actually proposed another project in my SOGP focused on building a decentralized, crowd-sourced emergency response service. However, my focus changed to the rail industry quite quickly once I started classes and assessed my opportunities. For an MSc. in Entrepreneurship this is somewhat normal (to pivot). However, for more technical degrees it is more uncommon to drastically deviate from your SOGP proposal.

In what ways did London add or detract from your experience at UCL? 

I think London is one of the best cities to get an MBA or any other graduate business degree. The access to people, companies, and money is unrivaled by most other cities in the world. A major downside of living in London is cost. I practiced frugality the majority of my time while Fulbright peers in other UK cities (and other countries) were not as concerned on budgeting based on my personal experience.

For Host Country Engagement, did you focus on ways to get involved within the UCL campus or with London in general? In what ways did you end up engaging with the community? 

There are two main points that need to be made in the Host Country Engagement response.

  1. How will you act as an ambassador outside of your research/studies?
  2. How will you develop a support structure to cope with difficult circumstances?

From my experience, I think some of the best strategies rely on engaging through your passions/interests whether that is sport, music, art, food, etc. That could take the form of being involved with UCL or University of London student groups, however it could also take almost any other form. London is special because the opportunities are seemingly endless and a community can be found for even the most esoteric interests.

Again, I think the MSc. Entrepreneurship is a bit different because of the networking requirements of the program itself. I spent what felt like a majority of my time meeting with local entrepreneurs, engineers, designers, and investors. I also participated in hackathons and coding challenges. I think I originally proposed getting involved in a football club and volunteering at a local community kitchen, but my schedule prevented me from doing either of those things.

Any other tips or tricks?

  1. Start early (6-7 months).
  2. Revise, revise, revise!
  3. Stay strong even when success seems unlikely.

I did not start the application process with extremely concrete and succinct ideas of why I wanted to pursue a Fulbright Award. While I was fortunate to intern abroad at engineering companies in Seoul and Bangalore, I spent much of my undergraduate career with my nose in an engineering textbook or prepping for an exam. I did not take enough time to really think about and plan my 5/10 years goals. The application process really helped me to slow down and carefully think about myself and my goals, which really required months of time to solidify.

I did not get the Fulbright Award the first time I applied because I bombed the UK Commission interview. However, by that point I already convinced myself that the Fulbright-UCL Award really was the perfect opportunity. I applied again, gained better insight into the interview, and was fortunate to receive the award the second time.

General Thoughts

  1. Describing the distinctions in your field between the U.S. and U.K. shows competence and effort. If you can describe, as you just did, why  Kent is the best place to achieve your career goals (or follow your interests) then this will greatly enhance the strength of the application.
  2. Being able to succinctly describe your field of interest to a group of laypeople while still maintaining the interest of experts is key. Your application will undergo at least two levels of review; the first by a selection committee that will most likely be familiar with your field and the second by the U.K. commission that will not be familiar with your field. If you can keep the reader's interest/respect then you can tie it in with your career goals and make them excited about the impact you could have in the world given the Fulbright.
  3. Being able to succinctly describe your field and interests also reflects on your communication capabilities, which in turn reflects on your ability to be a good cultural ambassador. For example, while in the UK you may find yourself trying to explain race inequality, firearms, politics, and police brutality more often than expected.

items.title: HyperloopTT
items.summary: If you haven't had a chance to read the article on Glyde, now is your chance. My journey with HyperloopTT…
items.content_html:
If you haven't had a chance to read the article on Glyde, now is your chance. My journey with HyperloopTT began while pitching Flexrail at Founders Forum, the premier conference for founders and CEOs in Europe.

At FF, I met Bibop Gresta, founder and former chairman of HyperloopTT. He charismatically criticized the rail industry while painting a picture of how Flexrail could pivot to a new industry. Somehow my work with HyperloopTT developed quickly in the following months and Flexrail began to pivot into Glyde. 

I started on a crypto-currency project using Glyde as a blueprint to build a utility strategy for a new crypto-currency. I delivered a whitepaper to executive leadership and worked with them directly on strategy until the project was cancelled. After the crypto-currency project I continued to collaborate with exec leadership across a range of topics.

Overall, I worked with HyperloopTT across 4 continents developing strategy and working with stakeholders. The pictures above are from a few of those experiences.

However, it is important to point out that HyperloopTT is not an average startup. Harvard Business School developed a case study around HyperloopTT's business model. To summarize, Hyperloop has only a handful of full-time employees and instead utilizes a large group (800+) of contributors and partner companies to achieve business goals. These contributors and partners receive future equity in exchange for their work. I was one of these contributors and my involvement was part-time.

items.title: Glyde
items.summary: Glyde is a new type of dynamic pricing for transportation. So new that we created a new name for it,…
items.content_html:
Glyde is a new type of dynamic pricing for transportation. So new that we created a new name for it, flex pricing. I was the lead product manager and founder of Glyde and this is a quick story about it.

 

Dynamic pricing. 😬

If you are already familiar with dynamic pricing then you can skip the next section. If not, don't worry. I removed any differential equations and confusing economic notation.

What thoughts does "dynamic pricing" bring to mind? Uber surge pricing? Airline tickets? Dynamic pricing has a fairly negative connotation. However, in the age of big data and free capitalism, it is lauded as a technique the promises max yield and utilization of assets. The largest ticketing company for travel is Amadeus, a company worth 40 billion USD in 2018. Originally founded by major European airlines, it now owns the majority of the airline ticketing business and is a prominent purveyor of dynamic pricing.

There are countless guides on the internet describing how to fight back against dynamic pricing systems. While Amadeus does not publish what data their algorithms use, it is probable they use a combination of personal and system information. Their dynamic pricing website states, "Analyze flight offers that customers have previously seen and bought, in order to model future shopping behavior and calculate passengers’ willingness to pay - in real-time. Offer the right price for a shopping session and hit the optimal 'sweet spot' between raising the price to make more money per seat and lowering the price to increase the probability of the customer picking your offer." In industry speak, this is called optimizing loading and yield. Loading is a measure of asset utilization (a.k.a. Are there empty seats?) and yield is a measure of revenue or profitability per customer. Balancing loading and yield to maximize total revenue is the name of the game and roughly "loading * yield = total revenue". I'm sorry if you weren't expecting a deep dive on dynamic pricing, but we need to go one step deeper.

The reality is that loading and yield are somewhat inversely related. Higher ticket prices means that fewer people are willing to purchase a ticket at that price and vice versa. This is commonly referred to as price sensitivity. A good example of price insensitive customers are business travelers, who have travel requirements regardless of price. The challenge of dynamic pricing is to charge price insensitive customers a premium price (increase yield) while still attracting price sensitive customers with a discount price (increase loading). Traditional dynamic pricing tries to predict a customer's price sensitivity and overall market demand to set a unique ticket price for each [potential] customer. That's it. It's a simple economic idea that is quite complex at scale.

The reality is that these algorithms often use personal data that is either collected from web interactions or purchased from third parties to make price sensitivity predictions. Furthermore, I think there are valid ethical concerns of applying dynamic pricing techniques to essential services such as transportation. For example, do you think traditional dynamic pricing should be used in healthcare? So what is the alternative?...

How do you set prices and ensure public assets or essential services, like a rail network, are being efficiently used by the public? 

 

Glyde.

As we learned in the last section, dynamic pricing is a technique to increase total revenue by optimizing loading and yield. At the heart of dynamic pricing is price sensitivity, which is what dynamic pricing algorithms try to predict.

But what if there was a mechanism that removed the need to predict price sensitivity? What if a customer would willingly divulge their price sensitivity... to their ultimate benefit? This is the question at the core of Glyde.

 

In The Beginning 🚆

Glyde was born as Flexrail from Hacktrain 3.0, the premier rail industry hackathon in Europe and possibly the best overall hackathon... ever. Hacktrain 3.0 was a 48-hour marathon that took place on moving trains across Europe with stops across 9 different venues. Here is a written account of the event from they folks at SilverRail. Or better yet, watch the official video below.

If the video didn't already spoil it, Flexrail placed first in the competition. I was the team lead and pitched the product at the finals.

Hacktrain was not the only success. I won additional entrepreneurial awards and competitions including UCL Bright Ideas and FFactor. FFactor allowed me to pitch Flexrail at the lauded Founder's Forum in front of founders, CEOs and even Prince Harry and David Cameron. Founder's Forum is also where I met Bibop Gresta, Founder and Chairman of HyperloopTT, but that is saved for another post.

 

The Flex Ticket 🍰

So why did Flexrail win so many awards?

Let's start with the Flex Ticket. The Flex Ticket enables customers to trade travel flexibility for discounted tickets. Ultimately, this allows rail operators to offer discounted tickets targeted at price sensitive customers with little risk of losing yield on price insensitive customers.

Let's compare the Flex Ticket experience to a traditional ticketing experience provided by Trainline, a leading rail ticketing platform in the UK.

The traditional ticketing experience shows a large number of ticket options to travel between London and Manchester. Users must scroll through all the listing to find the cheapest ticket that matches their travel requirements. The same tickets are also shown to every customer so traditional pricing techniques are employed to charge higher prices for services that are predicted to be more heavily used or of higher value.

Note: There are many nuances to the way ticket prices are set, which is the result of a complex relationship between the government that owns to the infrastructure and the rail franchises that operate services on the network. More on this later

Unlike traditional ticketing, the Flex Ticket experience is a two step process.

  1. The user picks a Travel Window (time window during which they are willing to travel) in advance of their travel date/time and are given an immediate price. This makes the flexibility/price trade-off completely transparent. They are issued a Flex Ticket which is a promise for a ticket during their selected Travel Window.
  2. Closer to the travel date/time, the user is issued a ticket for a specific train/time within their Time Window. Exactly when the user is issued a specific train/time depends on the rail operators pricing strategy.

So the main concept of a Flex Ticket is that customers are trading the certainty of their travel time for a price discount. This notion fits fairly well with existing economic theory. The more interesting insight is that the most price sensitive customer select the largest Travel Window. 

Price sensitivity = Flexibility = Time = $£‎€

Better yet, there is a near perfect linear correlation between price sensitivity and travel flexibility confirmed by over 150 user interviews. This is the roux of the secret sauce that powered Flexrail's algorithms.

But Wait. There's More.

 

Dynamic Load Factor Smoothing (DLFS)

The Flex Ticket mechanism allowed Flexrail to optimize the loading of high frequency services. 

Using historical and real-time ticketing data I built a prediction model to estimate future loading over an arbitrary time-span. This allowed Flexrail's algorithms to assign Flex Ticket holders to trains predicted to be less full. It is important to note that the predictions have accuracy limitations and only Flex Tickets can be optimally assigned. This means that DLFS will not solve problems like peak loading for certain commuter routes. However, there are industries other than transportation where DLFS is much more useful such as theme parks.

 

Why Flexrail Ultimately Failed

Rail markets are complex and slow moving monoliths. Unlike rail markets in countries where the entire rail system is nationalized, the UK rail market is partially privatized. The government, Network Rail, owns the infrastructure but does not operate any services. Private companies compete for "franchises" to operate a defined service or route. The franchises are defined with extreme detail and give private companies little flexibility to deviate from the franchise contract.

In fact, the amount of money that a private company makes from a rail franchise is stipulated in the contract. Any extra profit the franchise makes must be given back to the government. Ticket types and prices are also regulated by the government to varying degrees. 

These factors combined with the personal challenges of living abroad in London led to the eventual spin-down of the Flexrail business efforts.

However, this was the beginning of Glyde, a pivot away from the rail industry. A pivot that allowed me to work around the world with some amazing people. Read more about this in my article on HyperloopTT.

items.title: iMods
items.summary: A great smartphone makes tasks simpler and easier. Apple is famous for creating simple devices that make our lives easier,…
items.content_html:
A great smartphone makes tasks simpler and easier. Apple is famous for creating simple devices that make our lives easier, but with 300+ million users is a one-size-fits-all approach really that simple anymore? - iMods Pitch 2014

Intro

Apple has historically locked down the iOS operating system and the App Store to prevent users and developers from modifying/adding core features and UI/UX. This is especially true when compared to a mobile OS like Android. However, this did not stop tech nerds/geniuses/gods from "hacking" iOS, using techniques like code injection, to overcome Apple imposed limitations.

In fact, many features that we could not live without in current versions of iOS like cellular hotspot, mission control, notification center, in-app messaging, and more were all originally created and released by these tech/design geniuses within the so-called jailbreak community. In another manner of saying, Apple mimicked (ripped-off) many of the features and UI/UX enhancements developed by the jailbreak community.

Even Apple founder and tech god Steve Wozniak was a fan,

I have always given my support to the jailbreak community because they remind me of myself when I met Steve Jobs and how we were, then and for the years leading to Apple. -Steve Wozniak

iMods was born from this "jailbreak" community back in 2014. It was an ambitious attempt to modularize and appify iOS using jailbreak software as the building blocks. iMods was an attempt to solve two major problems with Cydia, the existing jailbreak marketplace at the time.

  • Piracy. Cydia enabled rampant piracy, hindering talented developers efforts. 
  • Usability. Understanding how to jailbreak an iOS device and what software was safe to install was a high barrier to entry. 

We created an App Store like marketplace that enabled an average iOS user to easily install vetted enhancements on their iOS devices.

Again, in the words of Steve Wozniak,

 I think it's a great thing...to make the software work exactly the way they need it to. That kind of hacking is the center of my heart, that's who I am. - Steve Wozniak

This was iMods.

iMods

I joined iMods as a co-founder and product manager in 2014. The majority of the team worked remotely and were located around the world from Greece to California. We also had an angel-investor that provided a group of local developers.

So instead of telling you about iMods let me just show you. The following image gallery details the original user interface mockups.

And here are a few screenshots from an early version of the app running in the XCode simulator.

We did a few things really well. User interface and community engagement were at the top of our accomplishments with buy-in from top developers and viral popularity from users. Here is a teaser video showcasing some of the software available on iMods.

There were also many technical accomplishments from a custom package manager to a scalable backend system (payment, account, support, marketing).

iMods was released under GPL3 on Github a couple years after the startup ceased to function. It can be found here.

items.title: I bought a supercomputer.
items.summary: IntroI bought a supercomputer. Well... to be more accurate I bought about 10% of the Oakley supercomputer which was managed by the…
items.content_html:
Intro

I bought a supercomputer.

Well... to be more accurate I bought about 10% of the Oakley supercomputer which was managed by the Ohio Supercomputer Center (OSC). The supercomputer cluster consisted of ~750 computers (nodes) that could be run in parallel for massive simulations and other technical computing. It featured a peak performance of 154.1 teraflops (CPU&GPU) and used an ungodly amount of energy. Oakley was decommissioned in 2019 and is in the process of being liquidated. 

However, decommissioned does not mean worthless. A single node from the Oakley cluster has dual six-core Xeon CPUs with 48GB of RAM. Performance is on par with some of 2019's best laptops (including Macbook Pro's) depending on the type of compute workload. If you want to see the full specs skip to the next section. 

Now you might be thinking, "Uhhhh why would you buy..?". Because Anton. More on that later.

Hardware

Even in 2020, these hardware specs are impressive for personal use. For the most part, supercomputers are all about compute density, fitting a lot of processing power into a small space, and that can be expensive. Each Xeon x5650 CPU in these servers had an original retail price of $999 USD. There are sixty-two x5650 CPUs in the servers that I purchased equating to an original face value of ~$60,000 USD...😵 

The server racks in the picture below are comparable to a Ferrari 458 Speciale, or A5 Waygu covered in black truffle if food is more your thing. They are top-of-the-line and built for performance, with a face value to match.

The server rack on the right contains 2U (height) HP Proliant SL390s servers. These 2U servers contain the (dual) NVIDIA GPUs. The rack on the right contains 1U SL390s servers which are CPU only.

HP Proliant SL390s Spec/Config

Dual Xenon x5650 6-cores @ 2.67 GHz
Dual NVIDIA Tesla M2070 GPUs
48 (8GBx6) ECC DDR3 Memory
Dual RJ45 NIC (1 Gb/s), 1 SFP+ port (10 Gb/s), 1 QSFP port (40 Gb/s)
Dedicated iLO3

The SL390s is part of HP's "scalable" line of enterprise servers and is a tray configuration. Each of these servers fit into a (HP S6500) chassis which provides power and cooling to all of the server trays. This improves density, efficiency, ease of maintenance, etc. If a server fails or needs to be fixed then it is simply slid out of the chassis while all of the other servers remain running.

Some of the server trays in the racks above were empty (no CPUs or RAM). Accounting for those empty servers I am left with a total of;

372 CPU Cores
1.44TB RAM
30 NVIDIA Tesla GPUs

Not bad. Not bad at all.

Power and Networking

Looking at the servers is one thing, but running them all at once in a cluster is a completely different thing. Each rack includes two large power distribution units which converts 240V three phase AC into the 120V single phase AC that the servers need. The connectors are monstrous and the cables are rated to 80 amps. Additionally, each rack comes with two 48 port switches (where all the computers plug into for network access). At the OSC, a single fiber optic cable (QDR, 40 Gb/s) was run from from the gigabit switch in the rack to the main switching network in the center which connected this rack to all the other racks. Modularity at its finest.

However, this is also the reason why I am selling a good portion of what I bought. It is unrealistic to run this in a home setting. Most homes are for a 100-200 amp service (at 240V) from the power company, which is 24-48 kilowatts. Running a single rack at full blast could consume 10-15 kilowatts (extremely rough estimate), and that is not even considering you would need to install special wiring from your mains box to the servers. So yeah, Anton is best saved for when someone else is paying for the electricity.

Why

"OK. BUT REALLY. Why would you.. What sane person would..." Please stop saying that.

So yes there are downsides to owning part of a supercomputer. Needing a commercial truck with a lift-gate to move it is quite inconvenient. Blowing the main fuse on your house is also not a lot of fun. I didn't even study computer science or computer engineering, so how am I supposed to know how it all works? Luckily, this is not my first server.

Back in 2013, I had a bunch of external hard drives with photos and video from my photography hobby. These HDDs also held a bunch of music, movies, data from experiments, and more. I even had backups of all of this content because my encounters with data loss were very painful. So to consolidate all of this storage into a single filesystem and make backups easier I moved everything into an unRAID server. unRAID is a linux distribution, based on Slackware, that was built for network attached storage (NAS) purposes. If you can build a computer then you can probably get a headless unRAID installation up and running for your home. Anyway, back then the community was small and you didn't even have the ability to run apps on the computer, it was storage only.

Fast forward to 2020 and virtualization has blown up in popularity. With technologies like Docker or LXC it is easy to turn any server into a personal cloud service (equivalent ~ Netflix/Dropbox/Facebook/Google Photos/Nest/etc) with free and open-source software (FOSS). 

Running a personal server at home means that you own and control your data. Privacy is preserved and companies aren't selling your personal data to the highest bidder.

Cut the the chase

Well, there are two reasons that these new servers are useful.

  1. High availability
  2. High performance

High availability - All computer hardware needs maintenance. Hard drives die. Components need to be upgraded. Things need to be moved for cleaning or constructions. If you are running mission-critical applications on your server like Home Assistant home-automation software, software-defined networking, or even a virtualized Windows desktop then it can be very disruptive if your server goes down for any significant amount of time. Using virtualization technologies like LXC or KVM in combination with a management system like Proxmox makes it easy to move applications from one physical computer to another with almost zero downtime. As I start to automate more functions in my living space and rely more heavily on the convenience of running my own server, it pays to have redundancy.

High performance - I enjoy using a small, lightweight laptop. Unfortunately, a good portion of my work involves heavy computation (video processing, machine learning, code compiling, simulation). Using this server cluster I can spin up multiple machines for a `torch.distributed` (PyTorch) job, a Matlab Parallel Server, or even a custom Beowulf cluster.

Actually Using the Servers

If you made it this far in the post then you probably want more details. I will split up some of this practical "how-to" information over a few posts to decrease the skimming burden on your eyes and brain.

(links will be available here as posts are published)

PXE Boot and iLO

Proxmox

GPU Pass-through

Docker and Portainer
